provisions.content: (1) Where Where a legally-assisted person or a lawyer representing a legally-assisted person becomes aware of a change in the means or circumstances of the legally-assisted person or in another matter related to the grant of legal aid to the legally-assisted person; and a legally-assisted person or a lawyer representing a legally-assisted person becomes aware of a change in the means or circumstances of the legally-assisted person or in another matter related to the grant of legal aid to the legally-assisted person; and the change is of a nature that the legally-assisted person or lawyer ought reasonably to suspect that the Commission might terminate the provision of legal aid or alter the nature or extent of the legal aid if the Commission becomes aware of the change, the change is of a nature that the legally-assisted person or lawyer ought reasonably to suspect that the Commission might terminate the provision of legal aid or alter the nature or extent of the legal aid if the Commission becomes aware of the change, the legally-assisted person or the lawyer shall notify the Commission in writing. (2) A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine of not less than two thousand penalty units and not more than ten thousand penalty units or to a term of imprisonment of not less than one year and not more than five years or to both. A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine of not less than two thousand penalty units and not more than ten thousand penalty units or to a term of imprisonment of not less than one year and not more than five years or to both.

provisions.title: Demand for or receipt of certain payments prohibited
provisions.content: (1) A lawyer shall not A lawyer shall not charge or recover from a legally-assisted person, an amount in respect of work assigned to the lawyer by the Commis­sion; or charge or recover from a legally-assisted person, an amount in respect of work assigned to the lawyer by the Commis­sion; or make a disbursement on behalf of a legally-assisted person. make a disbursement on behalf of a legally-assisted person. (2) A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine of not less than ten thousand penalty units and not more than twenty thousand penalty units or to a term of imprisonment of not less than five years and not more than ten years or to both. A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine of not less than ten thousand penalty units and not more than twenty thousand penalty units or to a term of imprisonment of not less than five years and not more than ten years or to both.

provisions.title: Expenses of applicant
provisions.content: An applicant whose application is approved shall be exempted from paying the prescribed fee in respect of the filing of relevant court processes; filing of relevant court processes; cost of judicial forms; cost of judicial forms; cost of service of filed processess; and cost of service of filed processess; and cost of preparing appeal records and record of proceedings. cost of preparing appeal records and record of proceedings.

provisions.title: Determination of appeal
provisions.content: A Legal Aid Review Committee shall determine an appeal made to the Legal Aid Review Committee; determine an appeal made to the Legal Aid Review Committee; give notice in writing of the decision of the Committee to the appellant within seven days from the date of receipt of notice of the appeal; and give notice in writing of the decision of the Committee to the appellant within seven days from the date of receipt of notice of the appeal; and record the reasons for the decision of the Committee. record the reasons for the decision of the Committee.

provisions.title: Effect and implementation of determination of appeal
provisions.content: The Commission may grant legal aid in respect of an applicant whose appeal to a Legal Aid Review Committee has been upheld. The Commission may grant legal aid in respect of an applicant whose appeal to a Legal Aid Review Committee has been upheld.

provisions.title: Right of Appeal
provisions.content: (1) A person who has been refused legal aid shall have a right of appeal. A person who has been refused legal aid shall have a right of appeal. (2) A person intending to appeal against a refusal for the grant of legal aid shall do so within seven days of receipt of the notice of refusal. A person intending to appeal against a refusal for the grant of legal aid shall do so within seven days of receipt of the notice of refusal. (3) The Legal Aid Review Committee shall determine the appeal within fourteen days of receipt of the notice of appeal. The Legal Aid Review Committee shall determine the appeal within fourteen days of receipt of the notice of appeal.

provisions.title: Alternative dispute resolution
provisions.content: (1) The Commission may arrange for alternative dispute resolu­tion in granting an application for legal aid in accordance with the Alter­native Dispute Resolution Act, 2010 (Act 798) if the Commission con­siders it appropriate to do so. The Commission may arrange for alternative dispute resolu­tion in granting an application for legal aid in accordance with the Alter­native Dispute Resolution Act, 2010 (Act 798) if the Commission con­siders it appropriate to do so. (2) The Commission may The Commission may pay for expenses incidental to alternative dispute resolution from the Fund; or pay for expenses incidental to alternative dispute resolution from the Fund; or request a legally-assisted person to contribute for expenses incidental to alternative dispute resolution. request a legally-assisted person to contribute for expenses incidental to alternative dispute resolution.

provisions.title: Powers of the Commission in respect of alternative dispute resolution
provisions.content: (1) Pursuant to section 49, the Commission may resort to conferencing sessions. Pursuant to section 49, the Commission may resort to conferencing sessions. (2) For the purposes of this section, “conferencing session” means a meeting at which a structured negotiation process takes place and it includes any step taken in the course of making arrangements for the session or in the course of the follow-up session. For the purposes of this section, “conferencing session” means a meeting at which a structured negotiation process takes place and it includes any step taken in the course of making arrangements for the session or in the course of the follow-up session.

provisions.title: Determination of pecuniary interests
provisions.content: (1) An Officer of the Commission shall not directly or indirectly have a pecuniary interest in a matter for consideration by the Commission or a committee of the Commission. An Officer of the Commission shall not directly or indirectly have a pecuniary interest in a matter for consideration by the Commission or a committee of the Commission. (2) An Officer of the Commission who has directly or indirectly a pecuniary interest in a matter under consideration by the Commission or a committee of the Commission shall disclose in writing the nature of that interest and shall not offer a service in respect of that matter. An Officer of the Commission who has directly or indirectly a pecuniary interest in a matter under consideration by the Commission or a committee of the Commission shall disclose in writing the nature of that interest and shall not offer a service in respect of that matter. (3) An Officer who contravenes subsection (1) or (2) is liable to sanctions by the Board. An Officer who contravenes subsection (1) or (2) is liable to sanctions by the Board.

provisions.title: Privileged information
provisions.content: Where the Commission or a Committee makes a publication during a conferencing session; the Commission or a Committee makes a publication during a conferencing session; a document is sent to a convenor of a conferencing session or to the Commission for a conferencing session to be arranged; or a document is sent to a convenor of a conferencing session or to the Commission for a conferencing session to be arranged; or a convenor of a conferencing session prepares a document; a convenor of a conferencing session prepares a document; the information is privileged.

provisions.title: Disclosure of privileged information
provisions.content: A convenor of a conferencing session may disclose information to the Commission or to a committee of the Commission if there is reasonable ground to believe that the disclosure is necessary to prevent or minimise the danger of injury to a person or damage to property; there is reasonable ground to believe that the disclosure is necessary to prevent or minimise the danger of injury to a person or damage to property; the disclosure is reasonably required for the purpose of referring a party to a conferencing session to aid in the resolution of a dispute between parties; or the disclosure is reasonably required for the purpose of referring a party to a conferencing session to aid in the resolution of a dispute between parties; or the disclosure is in accordance with a relevant enactment. the disclosure is in accordance with a relevant enactment.

provisions.title: Immunity for convenors of conferencing session
provisions.content: A convenor is not liable for an action taken in good faith for the purpose of a conferencing session. A convenor is not liable for an action taken in good faith for the purpose of a conferencing session.

provisions.title: Offences
provisions.content: (1) A person who makes a false declaration in an application commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine of not less than one hundred and fifty penalty units and not more than two hundred and fifty penalty units or to a term of imprisonment of not less than one year and not more than two years or to both. A person who makes a false declaration in an application commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine of not less than one hundred and fifty penalty units and not more than two hundred and fifty penalty units or to a term of imprisonment of not less than one year and not more than two years or to both. (2) A person who contravenes a provision of this Act for which a penalty is not provided commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine of not less than two thousand five hundred penalty units and not more than five thousand penalty units or to a term of imprisonment of not less than five years and not more than ten years or to both. A person who contravenes a provision of this Act for which a penalty is not provided commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine of not less than two thousand five hundred penalty units and not more than five thousand penalty units or to a term of imprisonment of not less than five years and not more than ten years or to both.

provisions.title: Guidelines
provisions.content: The Minister may, on the advice of the Commission, make Guidelines in the form of a Legal Aid Guide for purposes of the admin­istration of the Commission. The Minister may, on the advice of the Commission, make Guidelines in the form of a Legal Aid Guide for purposes of the admin­istration of the Commission.

provisions.title: Regulations
provisions.content: (1) The Minister may, by Constitutional Instrument, make Regulations to The Minister may, by Constitutional Instrument, make Regulations to provide for the operation of the Commission; and provide for the operation of the Commission; and provide for any other matter necessary for the effective implementation of the provisions of this Act. provide for any other matter necessary for the effective implementation of the provisions of this Act. (2) A person who commits an offence under the Regulations is liable on summary conviction to a fine of not more than five thousand penalty units. A person who commits an offence under the Regulations is liable on summary conviction to a fine of not more than five thousand penalty units.

provisions.title: Interpretation
provisions.content: In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires,“application” means an application for legal aid made to the Commission;“Commission” means the Legal Aid Commission;“conferencing” means a structured negotiation process that takes place in the course of a programme approved by the Commission and in which the convenor assists the parties to a dispute to settle the dispute;“conferencing session” means a meeting at which a structured negotiation process takes place and includes any step taken in the course of making arrangements for the session or in the course of the follow-up session;“convenor of a conferencing session” means a person to whom a matter has been referred for conferencing;“Fund” means the Legal Aid Fund established under section 31;“juvenile” means a person who is under the age of eighteen years who is in conflict with the law;“legally-assisted person” means a person to whom legal aid has been granted;“means test” means the process by which the Commission determines the ability of an individual or household to pay varying levels of contributions to the Commission;“Minister” means the Minister responsible for Justice; and“Officer of the Legal Aid Commission” means personnel appointed under sections 18 and 19. In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires, “application” means an application for legal aid made to the Commission; “Commission” means the Legal Aid Commission; “conferencing” means a structured negotiation process that takes place in the course of a programme approved by the Commission and in which the convenor assists the parties to a dispute to settle the dispute; “conferencing session” means a meeting at which a structured negotiation process takes place and includes any step taken in the course of making arrangements for the session or in the course of the follow-up session; “convenor of a conferencing session” means a person to whom a matter has been referred for conferencing; “Fund” means the Legal Aid Fund established under section 31; “juvenile” means a person who is under the age of eighteen years who is in conflict with the law; “legally-assisted person” means a person to whom legal aid has been granted; “means test” means the process by which the Commission determines the ability of an individual or household to pay varying levels of contributions to the Commission; “Minister” means the Minister responsible for Justice; and “Officer of the Legal Aid Commission” means personnel appointed under sections 18 and 19.

provisions.title: Consequential amendments
provisions.content: (1) A person other than A person other than the Attorney-General; the Attorney-General; an officer of the Office of the Attorney-General; or an officer of the Office of the Attorney-General; or a lawyer appointed for the Commission under paragraph (a) of subsection (1) of section 18 a lawyer appointed for the Commission under paragraph (a) of subsection (1) of section 18 shall not practise as a Solicitor unless that person has in respect of that practice a valid annual solicitor’s licence issued by the Council duly stamped and in the form set out in the Second Schedule."

provisions.title: Repeal and savings
provisions.content: (1) The Legal Aid Scheme Act, 1997 (Act 542) is repealed. The Legal Aid Scheme Act, 1997 (Act 542) is repealed. (2) Despite the repeal of Act 542, the notices, orders, directions, appointments or any other act lawfully made or done under the repealed enactment and in force immediately before the commencement of this Act shall be considered to have been made or done under this Act and shall continue to have effect until reviewed, cancelled or terminated. Despite the repeal of Act 542, the notices, orders, directions, appointments or any other act lawfully made or done under the repealed enactment and in force immediately before the commencement of this Act shall be considered to have been made or done under this Act and shall continue to have effect until reviewed, cancelled or terminated. (3) Documents in use, prepared or issued under Act 542 immediately before the coming into force of this Act shall continue in force as if kept, prepared or issued under the corresponding provisions of this Act. Documents in use, prepared or issued under Act 542 immediately before the coming into force of this Act shall continue in force as if kept, prepared or issued under the corresponding provisions of this Act.

provisions.title: Transitional provisions
provisions.content: (1) The rights, assets and liabilities accrued in respect of the properties vested in the Scheme established under the Legal Aid Scheme Act, 1997 (Act 542) immediately before the coming into force of this Act and the persons employed by the Scheme shall be transferred to the Legal Aid Commission established under this Act and accordingly proceedings taken by or against the Scheme may be continued by or against the Legal Aid Commission. The rights, assets and liabilities accrued in respect of the properties vested in the Scheme established under the Legal Aid Scheme Act, 1997 (Act 542) immediately before the coming into force of this Act and the persons employed by the Scheme shall be transferred to the Legal Aid Commission established under this Act and accordingly proceedings taken by or against the Scheme may be continued by or against the Legal Aid Commission. (2) A contract subsisting between the Scheme established under the Legal Aid Scheme Act, 1997 (Act 542) and another person and in effect immediately before the commencement of this Act shall subsist between the Commission under this Act and that other person.
